DOC.HEAD: Music Syndicate Sues HBO; Could Disrupt Schedule
DOC.TEXT: The music syndicate BMI is suing Home Box Office to bar the cable company from broadcasting BMI-copyrighted songs, which are used in a number of movies HBO has scheduled to run. In a suit filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan Thursday, BMI asked that HBO be barred from transmitting the songs after Sunday, when the companies' licensing agreement ends. Judge Vincent Broderick declined to issue an immediate bar, scheduling fuller arguments before another judge, Pierre Leval, on Tuesday. BMI, or Broadcast Music Inc., represents more than 100,000 composers and publishers of more than 1.5 million songs, collecting a contracted fee whenever one of its songs is played. It licenses radio and television stations, hotel and restaurant chains, even discotheques. The suit comes amid efforts by BMI to boost its cable television levies. Beyond raising basic rates, BMI wants to collect from local cable systems as well as from cable programmers. It now charges programmers alone. The suit said negotiations between BMI and HBO on a new contract had been fruitless. Ahrold declined to say what HBO currently pays BMI or how much more BMI wants. The suit listed 11 films in HBO's January schedule that include BMI songs, including the Beatles' ``Helter Skelter'' in the movie ``U2 Rattle and Hum,'' the song ``Strangers in the Night'' in ``Fright Night'' and George Thorogood's ``Bad to the Bone,'' heard in ``Talk Radio.'' BMI has sued several other cable television programmers alleging copyright infringement this year, but Thursday's suit was its first seeking to prevent transmissions in advance, said BMI spokesman Robbin Ahrold. BMI President Frances W. Preston said its rates for cable television have been discounted while the industry developed, but ``must now be brought into line with the full value of the use of the BMI repertoire.'' Moreover, under BMI's reading of copyright law, ``License fees must be paid by both the programmer and the local system operator, each of whom receives revenues for the use of BMI's repertoire,'' she said. Ahrold likened the concept to a hotel piping radio music into its halls: Both the radio station and the hotel must pay BMI, he said. HBO, owned by Time-Warner Inc., has more than 23 million subscribers, making it the largest pay-television service in the nation, according to BMI's suit. HBO spokesman Jim Noonan said he had not seen the suit and could not comment on it, but he said HBO still was negotiating with BMI on a new contract.
